description: From Middle English biheste, from Old English behǣs (“vow, promise”), from Proto-West Germanic *bihaisi, from *bi- (“be-”) +‎ *haisi (“command”), from Proto-Germanic *haisiz, from *haitaną (“to command”). Final -t by analogy with other similar words in -t. Related to Old English behātan (“to command, promise”), Middle Low German beheit, behēt (“a promise”). Compare also hest (“command”), hight.

entries.meaning: A command, bidding; sometimes also, an authoritative request; now usually in the phrase at the behest of. [from 12th c.]
examples: the House of Representatives will try to water down even this feeble effort at the behest of the unions whose members enjoy some of the most lavish policies.
The time is come that I should send it her, if I keep the behest that I have made.

verbs.description: behest (third-person singular simple present behests, present participle behesting, simple past and past participle behested)
